sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving acids and bases
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to form sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O)? The balanced equation for the reaction is:

HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O (l)

Assume that the reaction is carried out under standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm pressure) and that all reactants and products are in their standard states. Use the standard enthalpy of formation values given in your textbook to determine the answer.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction, we need the standard enthalpy of formation (ΔHf°) values for each substance involved in the reaction. Since I don't have access to your textbook, I will provide the generally accepted values for each substance:

ΔHf° (HCl, aq) = -167.2 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (NaOH, aq) = -469.15 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (NaCl, aq) = -407.27 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (H2O, l) = -285.83 kJ/mol

Now, we can use the following equation to calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction:

ΔH° = Σ [ΔHf° (products)] - Σ [ΔHf° (reactants)]

ΔH° = [(-407.27 kJ/mol) + (-285.83 kJ/mol)] - [(-167.2 kJ/mol) + (-469.15 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-693.1 kJ/mol) - (-636.35 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = -56.75 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide to form sodium chloride and water is -56.75 kJ/mol.
